title: italy schools closed until september coronavirus
story: He said the country will start reopening its manufacturing industry on May  as part of plans to ease strict coronavirus clampdowns.However, he added children will not be allowed toto their classes for another five months.We are working in these hours to allow the reopening of a good part of businesses from manufacturing to construction for May , Conte told Italian daily La Repubblica.He said the measures would be presented by the beginning of next week at the latest.Its path to reopening its economy is being closely watched around the world as other countries contemplate similar moves.Conte warned companies would have to introduce strict health safety measures before being allowed to open their gates again. px,px, px" data-img"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg stripallw" data-srcSet"https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w, https:www.thesun wp-content uploads   ac-graphic-map-covid-europe-APRIL.jpg w w" src"data:image svg+xml,%Csvg xmlnshttp:www.w.org  svg viewBox  . %E%C svg%E" Conte said schools would reopen in September but added studies showed the risk of contagion was very high. title: who are kim jong uns children
story: With the tyrant allegedly in grave condition after botched heart surgery, speculation has swirled about how the Supreme Leader will continue his dynasty.Kim Jong-un reportedly has three children with his we Ri Sol-ju, and they are thought to be aged between three and .The North Korean leader allegedly confirmed he had children in a conversation with US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo in April .In a discussion in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang about denuclearisation, Kim said he did not want his children to carry the burden of nuclear weapons when they took over from him.According to former CIA official Andrew Kim, who accompanied Mr Pompeo on the trip, Kim said: “I’m a father and a husband. And I have children.”He added: “And I don’t have my children to carry the nuclear weapon on their back their whole le.”Analysts of the secretive state say that Ri Sol-ju had her first son with Kim in .Cheong Seong-chang, a senior research fellow at the Sejong Institute in South Korea, told the Korea Times that the pair married in , and she gave birth to their first child the following year.News of the couple’s second child broke in an unlikely manner, when former NBA star Dennis Rodman visited North Korea in .Mr Rodman, who has struck up a friendship with the dictator, revealed Ri Sol-ju had given birth to a baby daughter when he ed.He later toldher name is Kim Ju-ae, and praised the tyrants parenting skills.He said: “I held their baby Ju-ae and spoke with Ms Ri as well. He’s a good dad and has a beautul family.”Finally, in August , South Korean intelligence reports said Kim’s we had given birth to a third child.Rumours about Ms Ri being pregnant again had spread after she was absent from the public eye for nearly nine months.According to the Korea Herald, South Korea’s National Intelligence Service announced the findings during a parliamentary session, but did not confirm the gender or name of the baby.It is widely thought Kim wants a male child in order to guarantee the continuation of his family’s dynasty.With the North Korean dictator allegedly in grave condition after a botched heart operation on April  , his line of succession has been subject to even more scrutiny.His sister, Kim Yo-jong, is seen as the frontrunner to replace her brother as supreme leaderhe were to die, but the country has never had a female leader.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: supermarkets add extra delivery slots lockdown demand
story: SUPERMARKETS will add , extra delivery slots to try and meet lockdown demands, the environment secretary admitted today.Mr Eustice confirmed during todays coronavirus briefing that .million slots will now be made available, but admitted it still will not be enough to meet all of the demand.He told the No press briefing: The food supply chain has also seen a signicant reduction in staff absence over recent weeks, as staff who had been self-isolating through suspected coronavirus have ed to work.Absence levels are down from a peak of typically  per cent in food businesses three weeks ago, to less than  per cent at the end of last week, and, in some cases, inidual companies reporting absences as low as six per cent.Mr Eustice said the Government had been working with local authorities to make sure all Brits had access to necessities.He added that half a million food parcels have been delivered to the most vulnerable Brits.He said: We recognise that there are others that are not clinically vulnerable and therefore not in that shielded group, but who may also be in need of help.Perhaps through having a disability, or another type of medical condition, or indeed being unable to draw on family and neighbours to help them.So we have been working with local authorities to ensure that those people can be allocated a volunteer shopper to help them get their food title: tom moore telegram the queen
story: CAPTAIN Tom Moore will be honoured with an RAF flypast, as well as receiving a personalised telegram from the Queen to mark his th birthday.Producers at BBC Breakfast — who were among the first to back the veteran’s efforts — have lined up a raft of celebrations to mark the war hero’s big day on Thursday, after working closely with Buckingham Palace chiefs.Tom, who has raised more than £million for the NHS and currently holds the UK No single, will have the entire programme dedicated to his le and achievements.A TV insider said: “The BBC have been championing Tom since day one and now they want to go all out to celebrate his special day.“The team on Breakfast have been working with the palace on organising the telegram in time for the morning broadcast which they hope will come with a special message from Her Majesty.“They have also been working hard on organising a fly past which will honour Tom’s service to the country throughout his le.“It’s going to be a really emotional day and they want to make it as memorable as possible for Tom by way of thanks for all he has done.“They’re lining up lots of surprises for him too. title: we salute the unsung heroes of lockdown
story: Doctors, nurses and other NHS staff fight to save lives, while an army of key workers toil tirelessly behind the scenes to keep us going during the Covid- crisis.As Boris Johnson ed to Downing Street last night, the updated figures revealed the UK’s death toll had hit ,. Many of those are key workers who risked and lost their lives helping the families of others.Health Secretary Matt Hancock joined us in paying tribute to them. He said: “I am overwhelmed by the outstanding commitment everyone has shown to keep the country moving during this unprecedented time.“Not only are our incredible frontline health and social care staff working to keep everyone well but they are supported by all the brilliant transport workers, supermarket staff, delivery people, armed forces, police, firefighters, teachers and many others.”Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said: “Our hearts go out to the families of all key workers that have lost their lives.“Every day during this crisis we see our key workers going out on the front line, risking their lives on behalf of us all.”Acting Lib Dem leader Sir Ed Davey said: “Our key workers are heroes. By working on the front line in this national struggle, many have made the ultimate sacrice as they fought to protect us. We cannot thank them enough.”London bus driver Emeka Nyack, , who drove the No from Blackfriars to Archway, is among key workers who have lost their lives to the virus.The dad told mum Anne he feared he did not have adequate protection to keep him safe. At least  bus drivers have been killed by the virus.Paramedic Ian Reynolds, , was the third member of the London Ambulance Service to die from Covid-.Hermes delivery driver Kevin Davies, , a dad of three from Stoke, died on April .Postman Akie Fenty, , was the third Royal Mail worker to die. Akie was rushed to hospital with breathing dficulties. Moments before he died he texted partner Lisa Masson to say: “I love you. This is f***ing crazy.”Carol Jamabo, , of Bury, is thought to have been one of the first care home workers to die.Her family described her as a “fun loving” mum of two who had worked in the NHS and other UK public services since the early s, after moving here from Nigeria.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Wendy Jacobs, , head at Roose Primary School in Barrow-in-Furness, Cumbria, died after being rushed to intensive care.Detective Constable John Coker, , who worked for British Transport police at London’s Euston station, died on April .He had been a police officer for ten years and was described by colleagues as “charismatic, kind and thoughtful.”Chief Superintendent Simon Ovens, of London’s Police Superintendents’ Association, paid tribute to the heroism of all officers risking their lives.He added: “Officers continue to do their regular duties while also enforcing the restrictions.“When you arrest someone, say for domestic abuse, you can’t maintain a safe distance. So they are all putting themselves at personal risk.“Officers also attend Covid-- related deaths in the community, both in care homes and houses.“When policing government restrictions officers have been asked to use the four Es — engage, explain, encourage and enforce. With enforcement a last resort.“But we are still getting lots of spitting at officers — who then have to go back to their families, who will also be at risk. It’s incredibly easy to criticise officers but I would like to hear people stand up and praise them.”Last week Prince Philip, , thanked key workers.He said: I wanted to recognise the vital work being done by so many to tackle the pandemic.“On behalf of those of us who remain safe and at home, I wanted to thank all the key workers who ensure the infrastructure of our le continues — the staff and volunteers working in food production and distribution, those keeping postal and delivery services goings and those ensuring the rubbish continues to be collected.”Here, we tell the stories of some of our home-front heroes.NAOMI Wynter bought her own face mask so she could carry on with her work as a district nurse.Naomi, , who lives in Highbury, North London, with her five-year-old son Cruz, says: “I visit patients at home who are too unwell to go to their local practice.“It’s scary now as we don’t know who has been exposed to coronavirus. Many of the patients are quite sick anyway so it would be very hard to tellthey develop new symptoms.“I bought my own face mask for £ earlier in the year. I’m glad I did as there is a shortage now and we haven’t been able to get any at work. They are now selling for £ online. The mask does look quite frightening so I try to reassure my patients.“Family members have asked me to stop working to protect my son, but I love being a nurse and feel proud that I can help.“I think the nation is finally beginning to recognise our value.”CLARE Batchelor, , works with the police and in her spare time foster dogs for a local rescue centre.Clare, from Axbridge, Somerset, said: “I work as a forensic paramedic at a local police station, caring for ­people brought into the cells.“People who have been arrested need to be assessed, blood and saliva swabs taken, injuries assessed and treated. It can also mean early detection of coronavirus symptoms.“When I get home, I foster dogs for rescue centres based in Cornwall, Devon and Wales.“Animals are being dumped as part of the Covid- crisis and I’m looking after them.”DANIELLE Whitham is a firefighter based in West Yorks.Alongside her regular duties, the -year-old is now helping vulnerable people by delivering prescriptions and pensions, as well as doing their ­shopping for them.Danielle said: “Since the ­lockdown we’ve been doing everything we can to help vulnerable people.“I sometimes stop for a friendly chat through the glass when I do my deliveries, and people are so grateful for the help.“Recently, I delivered shopping to a -year-old woman who is caring for her very unwell husband. She told me through tears that she wouldn’t be able to cope without us.“Last week, we drove to a hospital to clap for the staff, and many of them came out to clap for us in– I felt incredibly moved.“Members of the public have approached me in the supermarket to say what a good job we’re doing, and it means a lot to be appreciated.“It was lovely to get the Royal approval from Prince Philip too. I do worry about my health but I’m proud to be making a dference to people.“We’re all fighting this together.”JOHNIE Meharry, , is continuing to carry bus passengers in London, where  of his colleagues have died from Covid-.Driver Johnie said: “It is worrying to go to work. It is a hard time for everyone.“I have been driving every day this week and plenty of people are still using the buses in North London where I work.“At first the only protection we had was patching over the holes in our screens, but since last Monday the front doors on buses have been closed, so people have to board             at the rear. This definitely makes drivers feel a lot more comfortable.“The reaction of the public has largely been very ­positive.“I have been a bus driver for  years and I have never been thanked by passengers as much as I have in the past few weeks.“Drivers understand buses are an essential service, so that NHS workers and care staff can get to work.”ANDREW Catchpole heads London’s hVIVO lab — pioneering testing of new Covid- vaccines.The -year-old doctor said: “We have received a massive response from volunteers to take part in human testing with a non-deadly coronavirus.“Normally  would respond on our website in a week. This time we had , in a few days. People want to help.“We are trying to find a model that will speed up vaccine testing.“At the moment we are setting up the trial and testing the virus to ensure it is safe, before we put it into people. We will take healthy volunteers and inoculate them with a virus, making them sick but in a very controlled setting.“We are putting in lots of hours to get this running.”DESPITE being homeless, Monique Jones, , from Luton, is working in a care home for women with ­disabilities such as Down’s syndrome.She said: “Being a carer is incredibly rewarding. I work long hours but I feel I’m ­making a real dference.“I’m scared of catching the virus, but I’m young and we have PPE at work. I’ve been sofa surfing for over a year after being kicked out of home, so I worry about risking the health of people I stay with.Homeless charity Beam helped me get this job and on to a beauty course.“I’m glad to put aside my own challenges to help others.”MATT Spencer, from Banbury, Oxon, has been bringing in toilet rolls from home to give to vulnerable ­customers.The delivery driver, , said: “I love working for Sainsbury’s. People have been clapping and waving as we drive along — it’s a strange, but humbling experience.“We wear masks and gloves and I have been working  hours extra a week to keep up with demand.“I’ve had many vulnerable customers worried they might not be able to get essentials, so I started taking toilet rolls from home to help tide them over.“In one week, I gave out about  toilet rolls.”HISTORY teacher Georgina Bendall-Crawley is at Gable Hall secondary school in Corringham, Essex — taking classes of key workers’ children.Georgina, , said: “Usually there would be , students in the school — now there are ten to  so we are working with a skeleton staff.The pupils’ work is set remotely by their own teachers so we just sit with them, help and ensure they are safe.“Clearly I am worried about coronavirus but before lockdown I was teaching a class of  and sharing a canteen with  people. We have lots of hand sanitiser and, when I get home, I change and shower.“I’m young and healthy so as long as I am well enough to work then I’m really glad I can help out in this crisis.”WHEN it comes to taking on coronavirus, Danielle McIntyre, , is a pro.The Betterclean Services manager, from Plymouth, said: “It’s not often cleaners get thanked so it was lovely to get praise recently from Prince Philip.“The cleans I’m doing are in places like doctors surgeries. We clean ‘hot areas’, which is where patients with Covid- symptoms are put, but I feel very safe doing it.“We have protective gear and it’s incinerated when we’re done.“Knowing we’re helping and making a dference is hugely important. A lot of my normal office cleans have been cancelled so I’m working on sites which have to stay open like factories.“This experience, while tough, has shown we’re all in this together.”LIAM Jeff, , has switched from the recycling centre to collecting bins during the Covid- crisis.The refuse worker, from Redcar, North Yorks, said: “We are getting on with the work, because it is essential that the rubbish and recycling is still collected.“We do our best to keep safe and get back home every day. We have always had hand sanitiser in the vans and now we’re using it a lot more.“Inevitably, a few staff have had to self-isolate so we need people like myself from recycling centres to help out. The public have been fantastic — they come out and clap during our rounds and leave thank you notes on bins.“I have worked in refuse for five years and have never experienced anything like this.”TAHIR Ali owns a Premier general store in Jarrow, Tyne and Wear, and has been delivering food and essentials to hospitals, vulnerable locals and food banks.Tahir, , said: “When I saw there were massive queues at the cash-and-carry a month ago, I realised people would need help getting food.“I wanted to give something back to the community, so started to deliver bread.“Then I drove all the way to Glasgow to collect a van full of toilet roll, and started to hand that out.“I have also been giving out hand sanitiser, and , snacks and  cases of water to two of my local hospitals – the nurses said they hadn’t had any bottled water.“I get tearful every time I do a delivery. My heart goes out, I just want to help. I am not bothered about profit.”LAWYER Lorraine Lewis set up a charity to bring gts for cancer patients into hospitals — and the need is now greater than ever, with visits from relatives restricted.She said: “Patients are scared and alone, so hospitals have asked us to continue.“But now, rather than go on to wards, myself and  volunteers drop off the gts at designated   points.”Lorraine, , of Northampton, said of her Lewis Foundation: “Patients choose from gts such as toiletries, a radio, magazines or books.We set up four years ago after seeing how lonely patients were while I was visiting my mum-in-law  Janice who is now in remission.”A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mcdonalds drive thru coronavirus testing centre
story: The Foreign Secretary insisted the UK was “on track” to hit its target of , daily tests by Thursday.But he suggested the ultimate goal was to get up to , a day — and the process needed to be ramped up.It also emerged that million new “immunity” kits are on hold amid concerns of their reliability.The news came as fast food giant McDonald’s — currently closed — offered up one of its drive-thrus as a vital coronavirus testing centre for NHS workers.Instead of Big Macs and fries, desperately needed Covid- checks for frontline medical workers were being served up at the Meridian Business Park in Leicester.Staff from private medical firm DHU Healthcare were seen carrying out tests through car windows.Mr Raab warned tonight that a signicant increase in tests and a rigorous tracing of anyone who may be infected is the next stage of the pandemic battle.The Government is facing a furious scramble to hit its target of , daily tests by Thursday, the last day of the month.Just , were carried out on Saturday — the latest day for full testing figures. But Foreign Secretary Mr Raab insisted Britain was on target, and aiming higher.He told The Andrew Marr Show on BBC One: “Well, certainly we want to get , daily tests by the end of the month.”Askedthe , daily target — mentioned by Prime Minister Boris Johnson last month — was still the aim, he suggested it was.He said: “Well, we’ve certainly got to get the daily testing right up to hundreds of thousands.”Any ease in lockdown needed a hike in testing, tracking and tracing of cases, plus developing drugs to treat the virus, he said.An NHS phone app is being developed which will tell peoplethey have come into contact with an infected patient.An ,-strong army of human tracers will also help find and warn Brits at risk of infection.Ministers believe that by rigorously finding, testing and quarantining anyone with the virus they can help keep it muzzled as the search for a vaccine continues.Oxford University’s Professor Christophe Fraser, who is helping design the app, said up to around  per cent of Brits will need to download it — around million.Prof Fraser told the BBC yesterday: “We found that, for this intervention alone to stop resurgence of the epidemic, about  per cent of the population would have to use the app.“Now that number may be a bit smallerthere were other interventions going on which we hope there will be — social distancing, large community testing and indeed manual contract tracing.”It came amid reports the Government had ordered production of up to million new antibody tests by late summer.It is hoped the pinprick blood tests could tellBrits have previously had the virus and have built up immunity to it. But health sources last night warned it is not yet knownit is reliable enough to be rolled out.Ministers have bought millions of ious types of these antibody kits in the hope one will work.But so far chief medical officer Chris Whitty has warned they are not reliable enough to telliniduals have immunity.Meanwhile, testing slots for key workers ran out for the third day in a row — amid a warning from the British Medical Association.More than million essential workers and their families are now eligible for free checks. title: boris must ensure brits life
story: LOCKDOWN is over. Not officially. Not quite. But the dam is bursting.The trickle back to work is turning into a flood. People are still keeping their distance, but they are taking their hard hats on the Tube, visiting garden centres, coffee shops, parks — and, best of all, reuniting with their families.When Boris Johnson s from his sick bed on Monday, he must get ahead of this fast- moving curve. He needs to show he is back in charge.The PM has plans, yet to be announced, for “non-essential” stores to open. Next will be schools. This will be the “new normal”. Perhaps they should never have been shut in the first place.Polls show people will self-isolate, risk their jobs and keep indoors to save the NHSasked — but not land their children and grandchildren with the bill.They will endure a few more days of enforced sunshine but six weeks is long enough.Britain’s death toll has passed , — among Europe’s highest but far below last month’s scary , worst-case scenario.Lockdown has worked. It has taken pressure off the NHS. The “sombrero” curve has been flattened.Crucially, we now have spare hospital capacity and, despite a shortage of protective equipment, our NHS frontline has avoided meltdown.Yet we continue to hear the dismal dirge, “Stay home, protect the NHS, save lives”, to the muffled drums of the BBC and its throat-slitting Thought For The Day.While some are breaking those rules, many more — especially the over-s — are too terried to poke their nose outdoors evenit’s safe.So non-Covid hospital wards are empty and countless worried patients are missing le-saving treatment for cancer, kidney or heart disease.Others in lockdown are prone to mental health problems, suicide and fast-rising domestic brutality. More might die because of lockdown than from Covid- itself.The economy, meanwhile, is on le support. The UK “jobs miracle” is merely a memory. Some will leave lockdown to find their jobs gone, perhaps for ever.The Treasury’s mammoth multi-billion support scheme will leave crippling long-term economic wounds.One in four firms has stopped trading and Britain risks its worst economic slump in centuries.We are not alone. The Eurozone is fighting for its le. We may be witnessing the end of the single currency, an event which would send seismic waves around the world.THE furore over Covid- has temporarily eclipsed Brexit but the wrangle goes on.Strutting peacock Michel Barnier, used to getting his own way with Theresa May, has yet to discover the game is up. He wants Britain to give Brussels the same powers over UK trade and fishing aswe were still a vassal state.Barnier has yet to learn the shoe is on the other foot. Britain is now a sovereign trading nation.Europe is a busted flush. We leavenecessary without a deal. End of story.Russia, Nigeria and the Gulf states are being ravaged by the oil price collapse. Dirt-poor families in Africa and Asia — reliant on cash sent home by migrant children — are seeing those lelines severed overnight.In America, where Depression-style unemployment is close to million, the revolt against lockdown is already under way.Lockdown is prolonging the worldwide agony. This email from Cambridge post office manager and Sun reader Rob Swt sums up the view of many baffled Sun readers. Rob says: “We allow customers in to match the number serving and everyone has PPE.“At no point has anybody had symptoms or gone absent through coronavirus. We use our common sense then go home to our families before doing it all again the next day.“Along with supermarkets, building sites and some small shops, we have been open throughout and at no point have cases risen to the extent we have had to close down.”If lockdown continues for too long, many of those one- in-four firms which have already stopped trading will not reopen. High streets will look like a row of rotten teeth. Some school children will never catch up.On his first day back at work on Monday, the Prime Minister faces a tough challenge.An earlyto work will provoke left-wing charges that money means more than lives to the Tories. But livelihoods count too, whichever way you vote.Boris is right to thank the NHS for saving his le. title: the sun says best in britain
story: And my, how right we were.Our brilliant NHS staff have gone above and beyond the call of duty to steer this country through some of the darkest days in its history. We rightly clap them every week.But so too have an unsung army of binmen, postmen, supermarket workers, delivery drivers and cleaners.Their vital work stops this country from grinding to a standstill. While their energy, dedication and boundless kindness give a leline to the lonely and vulnerable.The shop owner who delivers food and essentials to isolated locals doesn’t consider himself a hero. Nor does the supermarket driver who brings in toilet roll from home for his customers.But only a hero would risk this deadly disease day in day out to keep Britain on its feet.Crisis or no crisis, they deserve our heartfelt thanks each and every day.AROUND , people were diagnosed with cancer last April.This month, top doctors would be surprisedthat figure hits ,. Why  Because conscientious Brits are so worried about burdening the NHS they’re avoiding doctors and hospitals.We admire their steadfast commitment to the battle against Covid- .Butthousands die because they didn’t seek vital treatment, lockdown ­— the ultimate purpose of which was to save lives —will have been in vain.Yes, some hospitals are more crowded than usual. But thanks to the sterling efforts of our doctors and nurses, capacity is increasing by the day.Your NHS is still there for you. Book that appointment today.THE newly recovered Prime Minister has a huge challenge awaiting him today: restoring the public’s waning faith in lockdown.First, he must use his incredible powers of oratory to remind fed-up Brits exactly what’s at stake.Then, he must clear up the confusion that’s crept in since he’s been away. Why, for example, is going for a drive in your sealed car banned, but driving the same distance for a walk allowed If our elected PM explains to us exactly what he wants from us and why, we have no doubt the country will sit up and listen.AMID all the doom and gloom it’s easy to forget all the good news at the moment.A whopping great asteroid will today miss Earth by  million miles.At least we can cross “getting flattened” off the worry list. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Speaking outside No. this morning, the PM warned the nation not to let up as he ed to work for the first time since his own battle with the virus.The PM hadnt been seen since he made a video statement to the nation on April  after spending a week in hospital.In his first comments to the country in weeks, and to reassure the public he is now back in charge, Boris said:Speaking today, he said: We are making progress, with fewer hospital admissions, few Covid patients in ICU, and there are real signs now we are passing through the peak.Thanks to your forbearance, your good sense, your altruism, your spirit of community, thanks to our collective national resolve we are on the brink of achieving that first clear mission to prevent our NHS from being overwhelmed in a way that tragically we have seen where.“That is how and why we are beginning to turn the tide.“If this virus were a physical assailant, an unexpected and invisible mugger, which I can tell you from personal experience it is, then this is the moment when we have begun together to wrestle it to the floor.”The PM also praised the nation for their contribution.He said: I want to thank the people of the country for the sheer grit and guts you have shown and are continuing to show.Every day I know that this virus brings new sadness and mourning to households across the land.This is the biggest single challenge this country has faced since the war, and I no way minimise the continuing problems we face.Mr Johnson has spent a fortnight recovering from coronavirus after a bout that saw him sent to an intensive care ward for several days.The PM, who was discharged from St Thomas Hospital in Central London two weeks ago, is said to have spent the past week easing back into his workload.He spoke with Donald Trump and had an audience over the phone with the Queen, too.Since leaving hospital, he had been recovering at his country retreat with his pregnant fiancee Ms Symonds - title: wristbands track every move coronavirus lockdown
story: WRISTBANDS tracking Brits every move could be used to start to ease coronavirus lockdown restrictions.The invasive technology could be added to the UKs arsenal of tactics to track and trace cases of COVID- and ensure people are following social distancing rules.Bulgaria has become the latest country to test the wristbands during the pandemic.Up to  residents in Sofia, Bulgarias capital city, will be given a device that record their every movement using GPS satellite.Other countries are also testing similar wristbands to enforce stay at home orders.South Korea and Hong Kong have been using electronic trackers.In South Korea, people found to be violating lockdown rules can be ordered to wear a tracking band, which alerts the policepeople leave the house.The trackers were introduced as people started to leave their phones at home to avoid detection.The devices also alert the authoritiespeople try to remove it.Bulgarias trial will test out Comarch LeWristbands, developed in Poland.But the technology has sparked concern from campaign groups.Privacy International said all new measures should be temporary, necessary and proportionate.They wrote in a blog post: When the pandemic is over, such extraordinary measures should be put to an end and held to account.The news comes as Brits started to show signs of lockdown fatigue over the weekend and headed out to parks and beaches over the weekend.Lichtenstein: one in  residents will be given a band to track temperature, breathing and heart rate and send it to a lab for furth investigation. Around , residents willbe given a band later this year.India: plans to manufacture thousands of location and temperature monitoring bands for people in quarantine.Hong Kong: police can be alertedpeople wearing an electronic band leave the house while under quarantineSouth Korea: residents issued wristbandsthey break lockdown rulesThe wearable devices could help the adoption of contact tracing, which the Government has said will be its cornerstone approach to easing lockdown restrictions.The test, track and trace programme will only be useful once numbers of cases are low enough that it is feasible to aggressively follow new infections and their contacts.Contact tracing, which has been used alongside lockdowns across the world, will keep a record of any new cases and anyone who has been close to them long enough to catch coronavirus.It could enable some people to leave their homes, while only those who might have been infected being forced to self-isolate.Apple and Google are developing a privacy-focused app using Bluetooth to automate the process, which the UKs NHSX is looking at.But any app would need at least  per cent uptake from the population - and about  per cent of smartphones in the UK dont have the Bluetooth Low Energyneeded for it to work.Some researchers have suggested simple Bluetooth wristbands could be used by people who dont have a smartphone.Christophe Fraser, of the Oxford Big Data Institute, said: It would be an option to increase coverage and there are also cheaper Bluetooth devices that could have the basic ality without being a full smartphone.Wearable Bluetooth devices could indicate in a very basic way whether contact has been made.Other methods of contact tracing could be by using text alerts, which can be localised to an area where there are new cases of coronavirus.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: coronavirus test kits run out
story: It’s the fourth day running workers in need of tests haven’t been able to get the tests they need.More than ten million essential workers and their households are now able to get checked for COVID-, as the Government races to hit their own , daily testing target by Thursday.But for people who are live remotely or are too sick to get to a drive-through centre, there is very little capacity.Health Secretary Matt Hancock has blamed lack of demand, rather than lack of capacity, on not ramping up testing faster.As of . this morning, home testing kits were unavailable on the gov.uk coronavirus website.Slots open daily at am.People are still able to book to get tested at drive-through centres in England and Scotland, but slots in Wales and Northern Ireland were listed as unavailable.To help hit Government testing targets, all health and social care workers, police officers, teachers, social workers, undertakers, journalists and supermarket and food production staff are now able to get tested.Mr Hancock said any essential worker who could benefit from a test, will be able to get a test.British Medical Association chairman Dr Chaand Nagpaul said there was no point setting up the online booking systemit didnt have enough capacity.He said: What we found in the first two days was that within an hour the bookings had all been taken up, and therefore offered no practical help for large numbers of healthcare staff.If the Government wants healthcare workers to have access to the test, it has to be in the context or providing adequate capacity, not a first come, first served and closing within an hour.Thats not delivering on the needs of our health and care staff.Dr Nagpaul added the testing capacity was well, well short of the number of healthcare title: public ask questions briefing
story: Brits worried about the crisis will now be able to submit their own questions to the Government online.Anyone over  can submit a question, with just one being selected each day.A Number  spokesman said: “I think coronavirus is the biggest health crisis the uk public has faced.“We know people across the UK are making big sacrices every day to stay at home and protect the NHS.“Its absolutely right the public get the right to put their questions directly to the government and its experts.”They will be selected by an independent polling organisation, and the Governments cabinet Minister will not know what is being asked before it happens.The spokesman explained: “The Government is not involved in choosing the questions, that is being done by an independent polling firm.“Polling agents will look at the questions and select who should be put to a minister and the experts.“They will relate to coronavirus and the health, and economic impacts of it.”Despite press questions being a live broadcast, the public will be asked to pre-record a video and will be unable to follow up on the answer given.You can submit a question here.It comes as the Prime Minister today vowed all decisions taken will be done with “transparency”.Speaking outside No. this morning, the PM made his first appearance since his video statement to the nation on April  after spending a week in hospital.He said: “I want to serve notice now that these decisions will be taken with the maximum possible transparency and I want to share all our working and our thinking, my thinking, with you the British people.”The PM also warned the nation not to let up as he ed to work for the first time since his own battle with the virus.He said: We are making progress, with fewer hospital admissions, few Covid patients in ICU, and there are real signs now we are passing through the peak.Thanks to your forbearance, your good sense, your altruism, your spirit of community, thanks to our collective national resolve we are on the brink of achieving that first clear mission to prevent our NHS from being overwhelmed in a way that tragically we have seen where.“That is how and why we are beginning to turn the tide.“If this virus were a physical assailant, an unexpected and invisible mugger, which I can tell you from personal experience it is, then this is the moment when we have begun together to wrestle it to the floor.”

title: kim jong un sister kim yo jong
story: With her brother reported to be ill, she has been tipped to take over the country should the Supreme Leader die.Kim, , was born in September , the daughter of North Korean dictator Kim Jong-il.She is said to have had a close relationship with brother Kim Jong-un from an early age.Both studied together in Switzerland between  and  with each depending on the other for company and support during those isolated years.It is believed she went on to further her education at the Kim Il-sung Military University and then computer science at the Kim Il-sung university.Kim is married to Choe Song, the son of top North Korean military official and politician Choe Ryong-hae, and has at least one child born in May .During the Winter Olympics, it was reported she was pregnant with her second child.She was very rarely seen in public until , when she was photographed at a party conference, but became prominent in the lead up to her fathers death in .She is thought to have helped arrange her brothers succession to Supreme Leader.Her first job title given in a state news address was a senior official of the ruling Workers Party Central Committee.In , In November , Yo-jong was named First Deputy Director of the Workers Partys Propaganda and Agitation Department.She accompanied her brother during elections the same year, signalling her increasing importance in the hermit kingdom.She was made a member of the politburo, the partys most senior ruling committee, in , giving her even greater power including over state security.In , she represented North Korea and her brother at the Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea.Later that year, she attended the Singapore summit on June  between Donald Trump and the North Korean leader.The dictators sister was spotted at the signing between the two leaders stepping up to swap a pen which had been provided to sign the agreement.But she was then demoted in , after she was held responsible for the failure of the Hanoi Summit, which saw Donald Trump scrap denuclearisation talks.At the  North Korean parliamentary elections, Kim Yo-jong was elected to the Supreme Peoples Assembly as a representative for Killimgil.In early April , she was reinstated to the party’s powerful politburo according to the state Korean Central News Agency.She has had a remarkableto favour after falling out of grace with her brother following her removal from the role in  and ordered to keep a low profile.She is now thought to be the mastermind behind Kim’s public image, both at home and abroad and is believed to have the full confidence of her brother Kim who is said to have had his own uncle executed for treason.Last month Kims sister made her first public statement, condemning South Korea as a “frightened dog barking” after Seoul protested about the North’s recent live-fire military exercise.She has also publicly praised US President Donald Trump for sending Kim Jong-un a letter in which he said he hoped to maintain good bilateral relations and offered help in dealing with the coronavirus pandemic.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBoris Johnson has warned he is not relaxing the coronavirus lockdown yet. In his first No statement since surviving Covid-, the Tory leader promised he would say more about restrictions in the coming days. We will at some point move out of the first phase of lockdown, he said, and into a second phase of easing restrictions while massively ramping up monitoring of the disease. But despite a review of the lockdown due before May , Mr Johnson said the UK can only move past the first phase when we fulfil five tests.These tests were first outlined  days ago by Dominic Raab, the Prime Ministeraposs stand-in while he was sick. Only once the UK has fulfilled these tests will some of the lockdown measures - though not all - be relaxed. So what are the five tests, and why are they so crucial  Here is a brief explainer.   The NHS is able to cope So far, the NHS has not exceeded capacity in hospitals - with spare intensive care beds and spare ventilators. But that is only because capacity was ramped up, including in vast Nightingale field hospitals. And more importantly, because lockdown has kept the number of critically ill patients lower than it would be. Government modelling predicts how many hospital cases there will be at the virusaposs peak . If the model predicts demand will outstrip supply then we canapost ease up on restrictions. It would mean doctors and nurses were forced to make heartbreaking choices about who should be kept alive. As Dominic Raab put it: We must be confident that we are able to provide sufficient critical care and specialist treatment right across the UK.   A sustained fall in deathsDominic Raab said earlier this month: We need to see a sustained and consistent fall in the daily death rates from coronavirus so we are confident that we have moved beyond the peak.The peak of recorded deaths was  on April , while the peak of new positive cases was , on April . But the new positive cases could shoot up now that testing has been ramped up to include key workers and their families. And deaths are falling, but are still at more than  newly recorded each day. Each one is a human being with a devastated family. This is a huge toll of people dying each day. Before easing up on restrictions the virus has to recede and let up on its terrible toll on the public.   New infections dropping enough Mr Raab said: We need to have reliable data from SAGE showing that the rate of infection is decreasing to manageable levels across the board. That means focusing on the crucial aposRapos number - the number of people each person with Covid- infects on average. If R is more than ., it means the virus spreads exponentially and soon runs out of control. At the moment it is between about . and ., but only because the lockdown is restricting peopleaposs contact with each other. Any small change could push it above . And that risk is especially highnew infections arenapost dropping enough - i.e.,the aposRapos number is currently only just below .   Adequate testing and PPE Dominic Raab said: We need to be confident that the range of operational challenges, including testing capacity and PPE, are in hand, with supply able to meet future demand. This is obviously about the huge issues in supplying gloves, gowns and masks that have plagued hospitals and care homes. But itaposs also about testing - and the need to get up to the governmentaposs ,-per-day target.  The reason this is so crucial is because only with a test, track and trace approach can we know early onthe virus is resurging in the community. That will allow the government to respond quickly before it gets out of control. The idea is to combine mass testing with an army of , contact-tracing staff and an NHS phone app which would use Bluetooth to tell youyouaposve been in close contact with someone oneaposs infected. This app and these staff must be up and running before the test can truly be fulfilled.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA Health Minister has tried to hose down claims Boris Johnson could announce an easing of the UK lockdown as early as this week. The Prime Minister is mulling when and how to relax some restrictions as he resumes work at full health in  Downing Street this morning. Allies of Mr Johnson - who survived a trip to intensive care with coronavirus - told the Dailyhe could go sooner than the lockdown review deadline of May . “There is definitely a sense that we could be doing more than we are at the moment in terms of people being to work, especiallythey are working outdoors, one said. The PM faces a Cabinet split over the timetable, other European countries moving to ease up, and pressure from Tory backbenchers - whose rep Sir Graham Brady branded restrictions illogical. But junior Health Minister Edward Argar - who was chosen to comment on the governmentaposs plans by No - today warned weaposre not out of the woods yet. With  new deaths being announced yesterday alone, Mr Argar said it is too early to speculate on lting the lockdown and now is not the time to ease up. Asked about the Daily aposs reporting, he did not deny it directly but told BBC Breakfast: I’ve learned not to always believe everything I read in a newspaper or beyond.  Mr Argar said Boris Johnson is back to full health and back at the helm today, chairing the daily .am Covid- meeting of ministers. The Health Minister added to Sky News: He will be back in the driving seat as we speak, getting on with the job. He is raring to be back and he is full of energy. But on easing the lockdown he added: I’ve seen a lot of the speculation in the papers and beyond in recent days. But the reality is we’re not there yet.  We’re not in a place where the science says it is safe to ease the restrictions. So we need to keep these in place to keep that infection under control and not lose the gains from all the sacrices we’ve made. The lockdown must legally be reviewed by May  - which is  days ago - and Mr Argar did not deny it could be changed then. But evenit eased at that point, it will not be lted in one go. Instead, the UK is expected to mount a phasedto a new normal rather than going back to how things were before. This could mean schools and some shops reopening while pubs, restaurants and mass gatherings remain shut.  A source told the Daily : May  is the day when the Government is legally obliged to review the lockdown measures butBoris wants to change the restrictions earlier than that, or at least announce something before that, then he could go sooner. The Daily Mail also reported today that ministers will be moving on from the aposStay at homeapos message to other measures. However, Mr Argar told LBC: We are sticking very firmly with the current message which is stay home, protect the NHS and save lives.  Tory MPs fear the economy will collapsesome restrictions are not eased. Sir Graham Brady, chairman of the  committee of Tory backbenchers, told the BBCaposs Westminster Hour: I think there is a recognition that we need to do much more to get the economy moving. There is a limit to how long people will tolerate those things, especiallysome of the aspects of the restrictions seem illogical. For instance at my local market, the flower stall was told it couldn’t trade, but in a supermarket of course they can sell flowers, because they’re selling foods as well. So ironing out some of those slightly silly anomalies I think would actually help to bring people along with some continuation of restrictions. Mr Argar said I totally get the frustrations but said: Really we do need to stick with this. He told Sky News: At the moment we’re simply not in a position to be able to make changes to that.

title: five living uk prime ministers
story: NewsAll five living UK Prime Ministers back Mirror campaign for medal for NHS heroesThe Mirrors campaign to Give NHS Heroes A Medal for their service fighting coronavirus has today been backed by all five living former Prime MinistersShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsThe Mirror is calling for NHS heroes to be given a medal " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Mirroraposs campaign to Give NHS Heroes A Medal for their service fighting coronavirus has today been backed by all five living former Prime Ministers. The clutch of ex-premiers set aside political dferences to throw their weight behind our drive to honour the brave healthcare workers battling on the Covid- frontline. The quintet – two Labour and three Tory – ruled Britain for  years. Now, they are calling for the incredible bravery, courage and sacrice of the men and women at the sharp end of the UKaposs fight against the disease to be recognised when the crisis has eased. Supporting the Mirroraposs drive, Conservative Sir John Major, , who was in power from - and introduced the NHS Patientaposs Charter to boost care, said: The frontline of NHS and care home staff are genuinely risking their lives on a day-to-day basis to care for patients who are very sick. The strain is no doubt felt by their families too, who must be deeply fearful of the risks their loved ones are taking as they help others. This is no ordinary commitment, and needs to be acknowledged. The campaign to award a medal to appropriate workers deserves universal support but, after that, comes a greater task: it is time to reassess the value of key services and key workers, and ensure that never again must they face such risks so unprepared. Labour former premier Tony Blair, , who pumped record amounts of cash into the NHS during his decade in Downing Street from -, said: “I wholeheartedly support the Mirror’s campaign to recognise the selfless and heroic public servants in our health service who are on the frontline against this terrible virus. “Every day we hear their incredible inidual stories, their personal and professional efforts to do everything they can to care for those suffering and keep us all safe.   “And we should not forget that they too are coping with losses amongst colleagues and friends. “The country can never thank them enough and we will be forever indebted to them.” Labouraposs Gordon Brown, , who was Mr Blairaposs Chancellor for  years and PM from -, said: “When in government, we created an Armed Services medal to thank all who had served our Armed Forces. Now, our nurses, doctors and NHS workers are today risking their lives to save so many lives and serving their country, just like those who served our country so bravely during war.  In every community of our country there should be the chance, through a medal, to honour brave servants of our country.  Tory David Cameron, , who was PM from - and once said his priority could be “summed up in three letters – NHS”, introduced the Ebola Medal in  for Britons, including civilians, helping the response to the disease in West Africa. Supporting our drive for a similar medal for those fighting coronavirus, he said: “The Ebola medals were a huge success and richly deserved. “I am sure the Government might rightly be thinking about measures similar to this to recognise and pay tribute to the outstanding and selfless work being carried out by so many throughout this current emergency.”  The most recent former premier, Conservative Theresa May, honoured the doctor who treated her Type  diabetes after she stepped down from No last summer after three years in power. Supporting the Mirroraposs call for a Covid- medal for NHS staff, Mrs May, , said: “Day in, day out, throughout this crisis our NHS workers and volunteers selflessly put themselves on the line to help others in their fight against coronavirus. “Very often this means sacricing time with their own families so they can help save ours.  “They are, as many have said, the very best of us and it is right that we find a way to honour them and say thank you on behalf of us all.”  No has signalled its support for our campaign, fuelling hopes that once the outbreak is over thoughts can turn to how best to recognise the efforts of those involved. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said last month: “The Prime Minister is very clear about the debt of gratitude which we all owe to the NHS workforce. “They are doing a fantastic job and I am sure the nation will want to find a way to say thank you once we have defeated this virus.” That was before the PM was taken to hospital suffering with coronavirus.  He spent three nights in intensive care at St Thomasapos Hospital, London, and later praised the personal courage of NHS staff who he said saved his le when it could have gone either way”.  They kept putting themselves in harmaposs way, kept risking this deadly virus, he said in a Twitter video after being discharged. It is thanks to that courage, that devotion, that duty and that love that our NHS has been unbeatable,” Mr Johnson added. Asked earlier this month about the Mirroraposs campaign to give NHS workers a medal, Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said at the No daily press conference: “The job they are doing is amazing, inspirational, we have all talked about it from these podiums. “Of course they deserve all the tributes and all the recognition and I am sure we will want to look very carefully at how we do that once we have got the other side of this crisis.”

story: NewsopinionCoronavirus infection may save the pangolin from cruel and illegal wildle tradeThe creature is believed to have been infected with Covid- by a bat and could be a factor in how the bug then came into contact with humansShareByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  APR NewsopinionThe pangolin is endangered " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis is the exotic ­creature you’d ­probably never heard of until earlier on this year. The pangolin, a scaly mammal that looks like an anteater, is believed to be a factor in the leap of the coronavirus from animals to humans at a market in Wuhan, China, last year after one was infected by a bat. This notoriety could actually now turn out to be a blessing in disguise. There are eight species, four in Africa and four in Asia – all at risk of extinction, according to the International Union for Conservation of Nature. Of the Asian species, two are critically endangered. They are illegally hunted and traded for their meat, which is considered a delicacy in some south-east Asian countries such as China and Vietnam. Their scales are used in traditional medicine despite there being no scientic proof of their ­therapeutic value. As a result, these shy, nocturnal mammals, covered in hard protective scales made of keratin – the same material as our nails – are now the world’s most trafficked animal. Back in , the international trade in pangolins was entirely banned by the  nations which have signed up to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species. But despite all species being given the strictest protection possible, the illegal trade continued, often with shipments of scales shipped out to Asia via Nigeria – the largest trade hub in Africa. An investigation into trafficking found the West African country was linked to % of pangolin scales seized globally between  and . Just last month, Malaysian port authorities seized six tons of pangolin scales hidden inside a container of cashew nuts and smashed a smuggling syndicate.  Another bust last year saw scales worth millionon the black market seized in Singapore. While pangolins and other bushmeats like bats were on sale in markets in Libreville in Gabon last month, sales quickly dropped as news of the pandemic spread.

story: NewsUK firms taking taxpayer cash to furlough staff wont rule out bonuses for bossesOnly % of FTSE  firms have committed to cutting bonuses for bosses despite some including Virgin Atlantic furloughing staff during the coronavirus pandemic at the taxpayers expenseShareCommentsByGraham HiscottHead of Business:,  APR Updated:,  APR News" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSome of Britain’s biggest businesses are taking taxpayers’ money to pay their workers’ wages while refusing to rule out bonuses for fatcat bosses. The High Pay Centre think-tank found that % of FTSE  ­firms have reduced boardroom pay. Yet just % have committed to cutting bonuses. It comes as Virgin Atlantic denied that the Government had rejected its plea for a £million bailout and that a buyer is now being sought for the airline. Boss Sir Richard Branson has defended the call for state help, despite sitting on an estimated £.billion fortune and with his Virgin empire registered in the tax haven of the British Virgin Islands. Virgin Atlantic is also using taxpayers’ cash to cover % of the wages of , furloughed staff. Another taking advantage of the Government’s wages scheme is tycoon Sir Philip Green’s Arcadia empire – whose chains include Topman, Dorothy Perkins and Miss Selfridge – for , staff. Fashion designer Victoria Beckham has furloughed staff despite her and husband David having a reputed £m fortune. The High Pay Centre analysed the FTSE  index of the UK’s biggest listed ­companies. The index does not include Virgin Atlantic or Arcadia. It showed at least  are using the Government’s Job Retention Scheme through the crisis. Over the past five years, those firms have handed out a combined £m in pay to their chief executives, £bn in idends, plus made £bn in profits. The list includes fashion giant Next, the owner of Primark – Associated British Foods – and Barratt Developments, the country’s biggest house builder.  According to the report, the  firms paid chief executives an average of £.m a year in pay, bonuses and perks between  and . In response to the crisis, a third of the FTSE  have scrapped or sus­­pended ­idends. And ex­­ecutives who have agreed to a cut have typically had salaries tem­­p­­orary reduced by between a fth and a third. Yet the High Pay Centre points out the average FTSE  chief executive is on £, a year. Many workers who are being furloughed will struggle as their wages fall by %. Some of the  firms have said they will top up salaries.  They include British Gas’ parent company Centrica and Premier Inn owner Whitbread. The Office for Budget Responsibility has estimated the cost of the Job Retention Scheme at £bn. Luke Hildyard, director of the High Pay Centre, said: “The scheme is a vital progressive measure to protect people’s jobs and incomes but it’s important to understand it is a subsidy for businesses, as well as for workers. “The companies will be under particular pressure to achieve a fairer balance between rewards for executives, investors and their wider workforce in future.”  Associated British Foods is only furloughing staff in Primark. A spokesman said: “Salaries for the executive directors have been cut by half at their request.” Next said: “With stores statutorily closed, companies like Next would have little ­alternative but to make very large numbers redundant. The ­Government provided this cash exactly so this doesn’t happen.” Next said directors have not been paid bonuses earned last year, will not get one this year, and have taken a temporary % pay cut, with idends unlikely to be paid during the crisis.

story: NewsMum lost st in  weeks after horric condition made her go to toilet  times a dayMum-of-two Trudi Stonard, , from Walsall, West Midlands went from st lb to st lb in just  weeks and was “lucky to survive” after being diagnosed with ulcerative colitisShareCommentsByKatie PearsonLucy Skoulding:,  APR NewsTrudi Stonard, , was ‘lucky to survive’ " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA woman nearly died after a rare bowel condition made her to go to the toilet more than  times a day - causing her to lose a staggering four stone in  weeks. Trudi Stonard,  from Walsall, West Midlands, was “lucky to survive” after she was diagnosed with ulcerative colitis, a condition which causes inflammation of the colon and rectum. In just  weeks, her condition escalated to “le-threatening” and surgeons spent six hours removing her bowel which was so inflamed it was like “it was on fire”. The mum-of-two started experiencing extreme stomach pain in December . She was even in agony when she ate a packet of crisps.She was misdiagnosed with irritable bowel syndromebut Trudi feared it was more serious when she started passing blood after eating “one bite of KFC”.Trudi dropped from st lb to st lb and her son Leonard, now seven, refused to go near her because she looked “unrecognisable”. She underwent surgery to remove her part of her colon and replace it with a stoma bag at New Cross Hospital, Wolverhampton, in February . Despite the damage to her insides, Trudi managed to “miraculously” fall pregnant with her son Bobby-Jo, now four, and has learnt to embrace her stoma. Trudi said: “In the space of  weeks I went from a normal person, to someone with a stoma bag. “The surgeon met me after my surgery and said he’d never seen a colon that bad. “In fact, it look so inflamed, it he said it looked like it was on ‘fire’. “He said: ‘I just wanted to stamp on it and put it out.’ While I was suffering from colitis, I lost around five stone. I lost so much weight people thought I was anorexic.  Itaposs been a dficult adjustment but Iaposve learnt to love my stoma bag. If someone offered to reverse it tomorrow Iaposd so no - itaposs part of who I am now. In December , Trudi started getting stomach pain and going to the loo more frequently. Things escalated in a matter of weeks until everything she ate was leaving her in agony and was rapidly losing weight. Trudi was diagnosed with IBS but she knew suspected it was more serious after she tucked into a takeaway. After ‘one bite’ she rushed to the toilet where she saw blood ‘flowingapos from her behind. Trudi said: “I never had any problems with my stomach until February. “Anything I ate, from a small snack to a meal, was leaving me in agony. Even a packet of crisps caused this crushing pain that felt like I was going to be sick.  “I went to my GP but said it was just IBS and gave me buscopan but nothing helped. “One night I tried to eat some KFC, I had one bite of chicken and I had to dash to the toilet where I saw blood literally flowing from my behind. Trudi went to New Cross Hospital, Wolverhampton, West Midlands, where doctors suspected she had food poisoning and sent home. Two days later she collapsed and her mum Jill Stonard, , rushed her to AE while she was ‘screaming’ in pain. Trudi said: When doctors said it was food poisoning and I thought: ‘That makes sense.’ “I thought that would explain why my stomach had been so bad. But when my mum found me screaming in pain, she took me straight back to hospital. Trudi continued to lose weight and was going to the loo over  times a day. In the space of  weeks she gone from st lb to st lb. She said: I kept losing weight and couldnapost keep anything down. One day I went to the loo around  times in one day.  The doctors tried to take a stool sample but the bed pan looked like someone had poured a pint of blood in it. “I felt awful and was barely able to get out of bed. My brought my little boy up to visit but he wouldnapost go anywhere near me. “He said: ‘You’re not my mummy’. That was devastating. Trudi was sent for more tests over two weeks including a colposcopy – which involved sending a camera through her colon. She said doctors found the lining of bowel ‘covered in ulcers’ and she was finally diagnosed with ulcerative colitis. Doctors tried every medication but nothing was working. In February , Trudiaposs last resort was to undergo surgery called a colostomy.  It involved removing the affected bowel and erting the end through opening in the tummy called a aposstomaapos. The stoma would then be fitted with a stoma bag to collect the waste. She said: “When they did the colposcopy they said my bowel was literally covered in ulcers. We tried every medication and steroid but I was throwing it all up. In the end, it was an operation or Iaposd lose my le. Surgery should only take a couple of hours but my bowel was so bad, it took them six hours. Trudi was told it would be dficult to conceive because of the damage to her insides. She was shocked to discover she had fallen pregnant three months after her op in June . Despite the odds against her, Trudi continued with her pregnancy and found out it was a little boy. “He was a total surprise – I was told it would be impossible to have a baby with condition,apos she said. Things started well but once the bump appeared, it put a lot of pressure of my stoma. I was told that I wouldnapost carry to full term but Bobby-Jo was a little fighter. The real problem was going into labour. I hadnapost been to the loo for ages, Iaposd forgotten how to push! Giving birth was the hardest thing in the world – luckily, he arrived safe and sound.

I was smitten and soon afterwards we moved in together. “It was small changes at first. He’d tell me not to wear make-up. Soon, the emotional abuse turned physical. Lucy, from Essex, said: “After one argument the neighbours heard the shouting and saw him being violent to me and rang the police. He had dragged me out of bed naked and put me on the balcony.” On Lucy’s st birthday last July, Ben set a dog on her. She said: “The police officer said Ben had locked one woman inside a house and hit another repeatedly with a bottle. But I didn’t want to believe any of it.  “The police officer replied, ‘I’m promising you, Lucy. If you don’t leave him now, you’ll end up dead’.” Lucy pressed charges, with a court hearing fixed for January  – but in December last year Ben took his own le, aged . Lucy is now urging any women who suspect their partner is mistreating them to contact police.  She said: “If you have any doubt whatsoever about the person you’re with, get them checked out under Clare’s Law. It could save your le.” Clareaposs Law allows police to disclose information about a partner’s previous history of domestic violence or violent acts. It was introduced in  after a campaign by Michael Brown, the father of murdered Clare Woods, . The mum of one was strangled and set on fire at her home in Salford, Lancashire, in February  by boyfriend George Appleton.He had a record of violence against women. Michael argued that her death could have been prevented had she known her partner’s history. Theresa May, who was Home Secretary when the law was introduced, said: Domestic abuse shatters lives – Clare’s Law provides people with the information they need to escape an abusive situation before it ends in tragedy.

title: ve day 75 years on
story: NewsVE Day  years later: The real story of how Britain won WWBritain played a far more dominant and skillful role in the Second World War than we often give ourselves credit, and with a pragmatic ruthlessness that is rarely appreciatedShareCommentsByAl MurrayJames Holland:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsBritain played a far more dominant and skillful role in the Second World War than often credited " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThere is a persistent myth about Britain’s part in the Second World War that goes something like this: at Dunkirk, the Army was saved by the skin of its teeth and not least by plucky civilians hurrying across the Channel in their Little Boats. With our backs to the walls, the Few – the Spitfire and Hurricane pilots of the RAF – then kept the mighty Luftwaffe at bay, Blitz spirit kept us going through the dark days of enemy bombing and, although we stood alone, David held back Goliath until the Americans finally joined in with their enormous material might. It was all a bit amateurish and Captain Mainwaring, but we stuck it out to the bitter end, although we’ve been paying for it pretty much ever since. Lend lease repayments finished only during Gordon Brown’s time as Prime Minister. It might surprise a few to know that almost every bit of what is written above is wrong. Rather, we British played a far more dominant and skilful role in the war than we often give ourselves credit and with a pragmatic ruthlessness that is rarely appreciated. Anniversaries are useful because they give us time to pause and reflect, and in this th anniversary year it’s no bad thing to look afresh at Britain’s really very impressive part in the eventual victories of . For the next three days, we are going to be offering a brief outline of Britain’s war, and today will be looking at the opening year up to the end of the Battle of Britain. It’s worth pointing out that no matter how diminished we might have become since, on September , , when PM Neville Chamberlain announced war with Germany, Britain was the biggest global superpower. We had the largest empire the world has ever known, and even greater extra-imperial assets. Britain owned huge stakes in Argentina, for example, with many farms, ports and railways run by British firms. London was also the centre of the greatest global trading network ever witnessed. We had the world’s largest navy, largest merchant navy – some , ships – and access to around % of the world’s merchant fleet. These were huge assets. Germany had almost no merchant marine, a very small navy and was virtually land-locked within Europe because the moment war was declared, the Royal Navy imposed a very tight naval blockade.The shortage of supplies, and especially food and oil, dominated Germany’s war strategy from the outset. Britain had a small army because we had a very large navy and rapidly growing RAF, and because its ally France had a massive army that was better equipped than any other in the world, including that of Germany. The trouble was, France was politically fractured with a coalition government of many parties and was unable to ever agree anything themselves, let alone much with their British ally. The lack of political direction had, in turn, a deep effect on the military leadership. So, it was not until April  that Britain and France finally agreed to mine the shipping routes in northern Norway to stop Swedish iron ore reaching Germany.  By that time, Germany had decided to invade Norway and Denmark and did so with clinical efficiency. After all, their lines of supply were much shorter and most of Britain’s army was in France awaiting a German attack there. Denmark was conquered in a day. Norway took until June, but although the British and small French contingency were beaten on land, the Royal Navy hammered the German Kriegsmarine, whose surface fleet was half destroyed and which never recovered. Then, on May , the Germans attacked in the west, pouring into France and the Low Countries with two massive thrusts.That same day, Winston Churchill became Prime Minister after Chamberlain resigned over Norway, so Britain was politically in crisis at the very moment the biggest clash of the war to date was beginning. Britain had sent  isions to France, compared with  French and  Belgian, so their contribution was very small. Nonetheless, Britain had the world’s first fully mechanised army.  In contrast, of the  isions the Germans used, only  were mechanised. The other  used what armies always had – horses and their soldiers’ own two feet. Only % of the German Army was fully trained. But those  German mechanised isions did for the French. France had plenty of tanks, guns and soldiers, but very few radios and, with telephone lines cut and refugees clogging roads, its commanders struggled to communicate with one another. But the Germans had plenty of radios and their infantry, artillery and tanks were able to co-ordinate attacks, while above, the Luftwaffe marauded freely because the French had no air defence system. This meant the Germans were able to pick off the superior numbers of French in penny packets.And when the French and Belgians started to fall back, the British Expeditionary Force had to do the same and ended up at Dunkirk.  When they had fought, the British had fought very well and effectively. Their counter-attack at Arras on May , , gave the Germans a real scare. It was the Royal Navy and the RAF – along with the superb defence of the Dunkirk perimeter – that ensured the bulk of the British Army got back home. Little Ships accounted for perhaps % of those lted and most were taken not from the beaches but from the East Mole – a wooden pier that extended from the harbour and which was untouched by bombs. The RAF of Fighter Command shot down large numbers of Stuka e-bombers and so it could be argued that the Battle of Britain began then. At any rate, once France fell in the third week of June , Britain was far from alone. The Dominions and Empire backed Britain, while the world’s resources were readily accessible. Although U-boats started making a menace of themselves, there were never more than  operating at one time in the Atlantic – and that was not enough to bring Britain to her knees.  We also had the world’s first fully co-ordinated air defence system, the entire Home Fleet ready and waiting to intercept any invasion attempt, and also “Harry Tate’s Navy” – the Royal Navy Patrol Service – which were fishing boats and crews converted to minelayers and sweepers, armed and also acting as an anti-invasion watch. There was also the Home Guard – more than two million strong by August , and not all Dad’s Army by any means. Nor was Britain defended only by the Few in Fighter Command. Coastal and Bomber Commands were attacking enemy targets every day, including four raids on Berlin before the first deliberate Luftwaffe raid on London on September . Aircraft production was more than double that of Germany in , intelligence was vastly superior and the Luftwaffe were hammered in the battle. The Spitfires and Hurricanes were not the last line of defence, but the first, and nor were they always outnumbered. On Sunday, September , , what became known as Battle of Britain Day,  enemy aircraft attacked London in the largest raid of the day, but were attacked in turn by  Spitfires and Hurricanes. Germany had planned to fight a short, sharp war, but failure to defeat Britain in  meant it needed resources from where, and realistically, they could only come from the Soviet Union.
